TheoremÂ 3.1 shows that the averaged sequence generated by Local SGD has an asymptotic normal distribution with the asymptotic variance depending on how communication happens (i.e., the sequence {Em}subscriptğ¸ğ‘š\{E_{m}\}) and the problem parameters (i.e., ğ‘ºğ‘º\bm{S} and ğ‘®ğ‘®\bm{G}).
For one thing, the effect of data heterogeneity doesnâ€™t show up in the asymptotic normality.
The asymptotic variance as well as L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} convergence rate is the same with that of P-SGD.
This is because the residual error caused by data heterogeneity typically has relatively low order than the statistical error incurred by stochastic gradientsÂ (Woodworth etÂ al., 2020b, a).
With the choice of Î³msubscriptğ›¾ğ‘š\gamma_{m}, the residual error vanishes much faster and then seems to disappear.
For another thing, it is quite interesting that the whole optimization process affects the asymptotic variance.
At the worst case, the way how communication frequency is determined only enlarges the asymptotic variance by a known scale Î½(â‰¥1)annotatedğœˆabsent1\nu(\geq 1).
If Emâ‰¡1subscriptğ¸ğ‘š1E_{m}\equiv 1 for all mğ‘šm (which implies no local update is called), Î½=1ğœˆ1\nu=1 and the result is identical to the typical single-machine central limit theorem (CLT) for SGDÂ (Polyak and Juditsky, 1992).
When Emsubscriptğ¸ğ‘šE_{m} varies, it is still possible to get communication saved and the asymptotic variance unchanged (i.e., Î½=1ğœˆ1\nu=1) simultaneously (see TableÂ 1).
If Emsubscriptğ¸ğ‘šE_{m} is uniformly bounded or grows in a rate slower than Eâ€‹lnÎ²â¡mâ€‹(Î²>0)ğ¸superscriptğ›½ğ‘šğ›½0E\ln^{\beta}m(\beta>0), we maintain Î½=1ğœˆ1\nu=1 and obtain a smaller average communication frequency (ACF).
In the latter case, the ACF is asymptotic zero, which implies that we trade almost all computation for nearly zero communication without any sacrifice for statistical efficiency.
However, if Emsubscriptğ¸ğ‘šE_{m} grows like Eâ€‹mÎ²â€‹(Î²âˆˆ(0,1))ğ¸superscriptğ‘šğ›½ğ›½01Em^{\beta}\ (\beta\in(0,1)), though its ACF decays much more rapidly than that of Eâ€‹lnÎ²â¡mğ¸superscriptğ›½ğ‘šE\ln^{\beta}m, the asymptotic variance is increased by a factor of Î½=(1âˆ’Î²2)âˆ’1ğœˆsuperscript1superscriptğ›½21\nu=(1-\beta^{2})^{-1}.
It depicts a trade-off between communication efficiency and statistical efficiency when Emsubscriptğ¸ğ‘šE_{m} grows too fast.
Finally, Emsubscriptğ¸ğ‘šE_{m} could not grows like Eâ€‹mÎ²â€‹(Î²>1)ğ¸superscriptğ‘šğ›½ğ›½1Em^{\beta}\ (\beta>1) or even exponentially fast, because this will violate the requirement âˆ‘m=0Tâˆ’1Emâˆ’1â†’âˆâ†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘š0ğ‘‡1superscriptsubscriptğ¸ğ‘š1\sum_{m=0}^{T-1}E_{m}^{-1}\to\infty that is inherent from AssumptionÂ 3.4.

When E=1ğ¸1E=1, it reduces to the single-machine result that is recently obtained byÂ Lee etÂ al. (2021).
Once E>1ğ¸1E>1, an interesting observation is that local updates reduce the scale of the Brown motion.
As an extreme case, the scale vanishes and the Brown motion degenerates when E=âˆğ¸E=\infty.
It makes sense because when E=âˆğ¸E=\infty, ğ’™tmkâ‰¡ğ’™kâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ’™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘˜{\bm{x}}_{t_{m}}^{k}\equiv{\bm{x}}_{k}^{*} and ğ’™Â¯tmâ‰¡âˆ‘k=1Kpkâ€‹ğ’™tmksubscriptÂ¯ğ’™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ’™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ‘˜\bar{\bm{x}}_{t_{m}}\equiv\sum_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}{\bm{x}}_{t_{m}}^{k}, the process degenerates.
Beyond constant Emâ‰¡Esubscriptğ¸ğ‘šğ¸E_{m}\equiv E, TheoremÂ 4.2 also embraces mildly increasing {Em}subscriptğ¸ğ‘š\{E_{m}\} (see TableÂ 1).

With this gÎ²â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘”ğ›½â‹…g_{\beta}(\cdot), we denote the random variable given inÂ (7) by tâˆ—â€‹(Î²)superscriptğ‘¡ğ›½t^{*}(\beta) and the corresponding critical value by qÎ±,Î²:=minâ¡{t:â„™â€‹(tâˆ—â€‹(Î²)â‰¤t)â‰¥1âˆ’Î±}assignsubscriptğ‘ğ›¼ğ›½:ğ‘¡â„™superscriptğ‘¡ğ›½ğ‘¡1ğ›¼q_{\alpha,\beta}:=\min\{t:{\mathbb{P}}(t^{*}(\beta)\leq t)\geq 1-\alpha\}.
The limiting distribution tâˆ—â€‹(Î²)superscriptğ‘¡ğ›½t^{*}(\beta) is mixed normal and symmetric around zero.
For easy reference, critical values of tâˆ—â€‹(Î²)superscriptğ‘¡ğ›½t^{*}(\beta) are computed via simulations and listed in TableÂ 2.
In particular, the Brownian motion B1â€‹(â‹…)subscriptğµ1â‹…B_{1}(\cdot) is approximated by normalized sums of i.i.d.Â ğ’©â€‹(0,1)ğ’©01{\mathcal{N}}(0,1) pseudo random deviates using 1,000 steps and 50,000 replications.
We then smooth the 50,000 realizations by standard Gaussian-kernels techniques with the bandwidth selected according to Scottâ€™s ruleÂ (Scott, 2015).
Kernel density estimation is a way to estimate the probability density function of a random variable in a non-parametric way.
Because we smooth the data, our critical values of the case Î²=0ğ›½0\beta=0 are slightly different from previous computations byÂ Kiefer etÂ al. (2000).
In particular, when 1âˆ’Î±=97.5%1ğ›¼percent97.51-\alpha=97.5\% and Î²=0ğ›½0\beta=0, our critical value 6.7536.7536.753 is smaller than previous 6.8116.8116.811, which shrinks the length of our confidence intervals.

We then turn to the empirical performance of Local SGD with limited computation or finite samples.
TableÂ 3 shows the empirical performance of the five methods under linear models with four different tTsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‡t_{T}â€™s.
tTsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‡t_{T} is actually the total iteration each client runs through Tğ‘‡T rounds or equivalently the number of observations they receive.
From the table, all the methods achieve good performance.
The random scaling gives better average coverage rates than the plug-in method, because its average coverage rates of all different communication intervals are near (or even exceed) 95%percent9595\%.
However, its average length is usually larger than that of plug-in.
Furthermore, its average length usually has a much larger deviation than that of plug-in.
For example, when tT=5000subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‡5000t_{T}=5000, for C5, the standard deviation of average lengths for plug-in is 0.807Ã—10âˆ’20.807superscript1020.807\times 10^{-2}, while it increases to 3.714Ã—10âˆ’23.714superscript1023.714\times 10^{-2} for random scaling.
Such a wider average length might account for the unexpected advantage on the average coverage rates.
However, as the communication round increases and more observations are available, both the average length and its deviations decrease.

In addition, comparing the results of Log, P(1/3), and P(1/2), we can find that the faster Emsubscriptğ¸ğ‘šE_{m} increases, the larger average length as well as its standard deviations. However, they all have satisfactory performance when observations are sufficient.
Indeed, Local SGD trades more computation for less communication, resulting in a residual error gradually accumulated when communication is off, slowing down the convergence rate and enlarging asymptotic variance (e.g., the existence of Î½ğœˆ\nu).
However, the benefit is also attractive: the averaged communication frequency is substantially reduced and the convergence in terms of communication largely increases.
It implies that Local SGD obtains both statistical efficiency and communication efficiency as expected.
We further consider the logistic regression, which is a standard non-linear model.
The result is given in TableÂ 4.
A similar pattern is observed: random scaling has higher average coverage rates at the price of wider average lengths which typically shrink as more observations are generated.
